semantic_title: Coding Acute and Chronic Conditions When Both Present
section_path: Section I > B. General Coding Guidelines > 8. Acute and Chronic Conditions

content.full_text: If the same condition is described as both acute (subacute) and chronic, and separate subentries exist in the Alphabetic Index at the same indentation level, code both and sequence the acute (subacute) code first. (Evidence: pg no: 14, L58-L59)
content.summary: When a condition is documented as both acute/subacute and chronic with separate index entries at the same level, both codes should be assigned with the acute code sequenced first. (Evidence: pg no: 14, L58-L59)
key_concepts: Same condition described as both acute and chronic (Evidence: pg no: 14, L58)
Separate subentries must exist at same indentation level (Evidence: pg no: 14, L58-L59)
Code both conditions when criteria met (Evidence: pg no: 14, L59)
Sequence acute/subacute code first (Evidence: pg no: 14, L59)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Code both acute and chronic when same condition has separate index entries at same level (Evidence: pg no: 14, L58-L59)
detailed_rules.explanation: When the same condition is documented as both acute (or subacute) and chronic, and the Alphabetic Index contains separate subentries for both at the same indentation level, both codes should be assigned to fully capture the patient's condition (Evidence: pg no: 14, L58-L59)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Sequence acute (subacute) code first when coding both (Evidence: pg no: 14, L59)
detailed_rules.explanation: When both acute and chronic codes are assigned for the same condition, the acute or subacute code should be listed first, followed by the chronic code (Evidence: pg no: 14, L59)
common_applications: Acute kidney injury with chronic kidney disease
Acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
Acute on chronic systolic heart failure

workflow_steps: Step 1: Identify condition documented as both acute/subacute and chronic
Step 2: Look up condition in Alphabetic Index
Step 3: Check if separate subentries exist at same indentation level
Step 4: If yes, assign both codes
Step 5: Sequence acute/subacute code first, chronic code second

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient with acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Final diagnosis: Acute kidney injury with underlying chronic kidney disease stage 3
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify both acute and chronic kidney conditions
Step 2: Look up kidney disease in Alphabetic Index
Step 3: Confirm separate entries exist for acute and chronic
Step 5: Sequence acute kidney injury first

correct_coding.sequencing: Acute condition first, chronic condition second
correct_coding.rationale: Both acute and chronic conditions present with separate index entries, acute sequenced first (Evidence: pg no: 14, L58-L59)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Would miss the acute component that should be coded separately
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Coding only chronic condition when both acute and chronic present

warnings: Only code both when separate subentries exist at same indentation level (Evidence: pg no: 14, L58-L59)
Always sequence acute/subacute first when coding both (Evidence: pg no: 14, L59)
best_practices: Check Alphabetic Index carefully for separate subentries (Evidence: pg no: 14, L58-L59)
Verify indentation levels are the same (Evidence: pg no: 14, L58-L59)
common_mistakes: Coding only one when both should be coded (Evidence: pg no: 14, L58-L59)
Incorrect sequencing of acute and chronic codes (Evidence: pg no: 14, L59)
tips: Look for 'acute' and 'chronic' subentries in index (Evidence: pg no: 14, L58-L59)
Remember subacute follows same rule as acute (Evidence: pg no: 14, L58-L59)
implementation_notes: Requires careful examination of Alphabetic Index structure
clinical_context: Common in kidney disease, heart failure, and respiratory conditions
Important for severity of illness and resource utilization
